For the last few months, the NuGet team has been considering starting a proper, official blog. This is that blog.

How do we plan to use this blog? Here are a few ways we know we’ll use it (and I’m...

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Packages stuck in "validating" status for several hours" (#5530) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
On 2/19 I uploaded a package. 3+ hours later it was still in "validating" status. I contacted support, the package was listed shortly thereafter, and the next day I got a reply confirming there had been an incident of some sort and it was resolved. Today I uploaded a package and am seeing exactly the same behavior. 2+ hours on and it's still in "validating" status.

The package in question is Flurl.Http.

Is there another incident or is this the new normal?

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "[Orchestrator] Delay the delivery of validation requests" (#5529) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Upon receiving a package's validation request, the Orchestrator polls the Gallery database once a minute until it finds the package that should be validated. Unfortunately, the Orchestrator often receives the validation request seconds before the Gallery has had a chance to persist changes to its database. In other words, the Orchestrator often waits a full minute to validate a package, when in reality, it should have only waited a few seconds.

This change aims to drastically reduce the time the Orchestrator waits to start a package's validation by delaying the delivery of the validation request by 5 seconds.

## Supporting Data

I ran the following Application Insights query:

```
traces
| where message contains "Starting Enqueuing asynchronous package validation"
| join (requests | where name == "POST Packages/VerifyPackage" or name == "PUT Api/PushPackageApi" | project requestTimestamp = timestamp, duration, operation_Id) on operation_Id 
| project requestTimestamp, validationTimestamp = timestamp, duration
| extend timeToEnqueue = ((validationTimestamp - requestTimestamp)/ time(1ms))
| extend timeAfterEnqueue = duration - timeToEnqueue
| summarize percentiles(timeAfterEnqueue, 10, 50, 75, 80, 90, 95, 99), max(timeAfterEnqueue)
```

This `timeAfterEnqueue` estimates the the time upload requests spent after the validation request has been enqueued to persist changes to the database (it also includes the package upload to blob storage). The breakdown for `timeAfterEnqueue` for ALL requests (including failed ones) since December 1st is:

10% | 50% | 75% | 80% | 90% | 95% | 99%
--- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | ---
2s | 3s | 3.7s | 4s | 10.3s | 12.4s | 38.6s

Thus, by delaying the delivery of validation requests by 5 seconds, at least 80% of validation requests should begin after waiting 5 seconds.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[NuGet Server] Unable to restore (some) Semver 2.0 versioned packages" (#5528) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
## Summary

It is not possible to restore some packages with a valid Semver 2.0 version from NuGet.Server. For instance, the package version `1.2.3-a1234-2` works fine, but the version `1.2.3-a1234.2` does not.

The second example is valid Semver 2.0 as per https://semver.org/

## Symptoms

* The package version does not show up in the XML served at `nugetserver/nuget/Packages`
* The package version does not show up in the XML served by `nugetserver/nuget/FindPackagesById()?id='MyPackage'`
* From the CLI, attempting to restore the package using `dotnet restore` results in the output below
* Inside Visual Studio, when managing NuGet packages, the version **does** show as available but selecting it and clicking *Update* also results in the output shown below

```
error NU1102: Unable to find package MyPackage with version (>= 1.2.3-a1234.2)
error NU1102:   - Found 99 version(s) in my-repo [ Nearest version: 1.2.0 ]
error NU1102:   - Found 1 version(s) in nuget.org [ Nearest version: 1.0.0 ]
error NU1102:   - Found 0 version(s) in local-artifacts
``` 

## Reproducing

```bash
mkdir net-core-nuget-lib
cd net-core-nuget-lib/
dotnet new classlib
dotnet build
dotnet pack -c release /p:Version=1.2.3-a1234.2
dotnet pack -c release /p:Version=1.2.3-a1234-2
dotnet nuget push /Users/nwoolls/src/csharp/net-core-nuget-lib/bin/release/net-core-nuget-lib.1.2.3-a1234.2.nupkg --source http://myrepo.example.com/api/v2/package --api-key my-api-key
dotnet nuget push /Users/nwoolls/src/csharp/net-core-nuget-lib/bin/release/net-core-nuget-lib.1.2.3-a1234-2.nupkg --source http://myrepo.example.com/api/v2/package --api-key my-api-key
curl 'http://myrepo.example.com/nugetserver/nuget/FindPackagesById()?id=%27net-core-nuget-lib%27'
```

The output from cURL above includes version `1.2.3-a1234-2` but *not* `1.2.3-a1234.2`:

```xml
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<feed xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom" xmlns:d="http://schemas.microsoft.com/ado/2007/08/dataservices" xmlns:m="http://schemas.microsoft.com/ado/2007/08/dataservices/metadata" xml:base="http://myrepo.example.com/nugetserver/nuget/">
  <id>http://myrepo.example.com/nugetserver/nuget/FindPackagesById</id>
  <title type="text">FindPackagesById</title>
  <updated>2018-02-21T23:03:15Z</updated>
  <link rel="self" title="FindPackagesById" href="FindPackagesById"/>
  <entry>
    <id>http://myrepo.example.com/nugetserver/nuget/Packages(Id='net-core-nuget-lib',Version='1.2.3-a1234-2')</id>
    <category term="NuGet.Server.DataServices.ODataPackage" scheme="http://schemas.microsoft.com/ado/2007/08/dataservices/scheme"/>
    <link rel="edit" title="ODataPackage" href="Packages(Id='net-core-nuget-lib',Version='1.2.3-a1234-2')"/>
    <title type="text">net-core-nuget-lib</title>
    <summary type="text"/>
    <published>2018-02-21T22:59:26Z</published>
    <updated>2018-02-21T22:59:26Z</updated>
    <author>
      <name>net-core-nuget-lib</name>
    </author>
    <link rel="edit-media" title="ODataPackage" href="Packages(Id='net-core-nuget-lib',Version='1.2.3-a1234-2')/$value"/>
    <content type="application/zip" src="http://myrepo.example.com/nugetserver/api/v2/package/net-core-nuget-lib/1.2.3-a1234-2"/>
    <m:properties>
      <d:Version>1.2.3-a1234-2</d:Version>
      <d:NormalizedVersion>1.2.3-a1234-2</d:NormalizedVersion>
      <d:IsPrerelease m:type="Edm.Boolean">true</d:IsPrerelease>
      <d:Title m:null="true"/>
      <d:Owners>net-core-nuget-lib</d:Owners>
      <d:IconUrl m:null="true"/>

      <d:DevelopmentDependency m:type="Edm.Boolean">false</d:DevelopmentDependency>
      <d:Description>Package Description</d:Description>
      <d:Summary m:null="true"/>
      <d:ReleaseNotes m:null="true"/>
      <d:Published m:type="Edm.DateTime">2018-02-21T22:59:26.8807552Z</d:Published>
      <d:Dependencies>::netstandard2.0</d:Dependencies>
      <d:PackageHash>EwclxIGcCHkNeKJ875v4OWLiU5hkhnc8PosCre4JfCauFkF9qDazbd31sUhZy6PyR0aOzSuvMbOAEUXErFKXdg==</d:PackageHash>
      <d:PackageHashAlgorithm>SHA512</d:PackageHashAlgorithm>
      <d:PackageSize m:type="Edm.Int64">3287</d:PackageSize>
      <d:Copyright m:null="true"/>

```

## Environment

This issue was reproduced using NuGet.Server 2.14.2.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Add telemetry around catalog index read and write" (#5527) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody: This is an unbounded thing in NuGet.org. We should have telemetry to understand how reading and writing of the document slows down over time.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Restore fails for AutoMapper when project is netcoreapp2.0" (#6445) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
The Restore step fails in my build definition with this error:

error NU1100: Unable to resolve 'AutoMapper (>= 6.2.2)' for '.NETCoreApp,Version=v2.0'.

This is in a .NETCoreApp 2.0 that is using AutoMapper. Restore succeeds locally in VS 2017. Locally I am using dotnet sdk 2.0.0, and nuget 4.3.1. On the VSTS (cloud) server, I am specifying the latest nuget version, 4.5.0. I have tried many other versions, including 4.3.1 with no success.

I know there is an older, similar question on stackoverflow, but that was never answered satisfactorily, in my opinion.

If I look at the meta data in VS, at the top of one of the Automapper files I can see this:

Assembly AutoMapper, Version=6.2.2.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=be96cd2c38ef1005
// C:\Users\randyg.nuget\packages\automapper\6.2.2\lib\netstandard1.3\AutoMapper.dll

From this you can see it's taking the netstandard1.3 version, which is correct. I'm wondering if the nuget on the build server is looking for a netcoreApp2.0 folder, rather than the netstandard1.3 folder? Following this theory, I tried adding this to my .csproj file:

<AssetTargetFallback>$(AssetTargetFallback);netstandard1.3</AssetTargetFallback>
My theory was this would tell nuget to look for a netstandard1.3 version of automapper if it couldn't find a netcoreapp2.0 version. However, this didn't have any effect. I later read that behind the scenes this fallback is already added automatically.

If anyone has any ideas I would greatly appreciate it. I'm pulling out (what's left of) my hair on this, as this is the only package giving me trouble, and it's a critical one for my project.

On the build server I'm using .NET Core sdk 2.0.3 as well, if that matters.

Update - I just tried adding a new project to my solution, with a target of netstandard1.3, then adding AutoMapper as a dependency. Restore is now working on the build server for this project. So it seems the problem is specific to having a project with target = netcoreapp2.0??

2. Build the project, then run `nuget pack NugetPackBug.csproj -Verbosity detailed`

This fails with a NotImplementedException when run on Linux (see below). On Windows things work as expected.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "nuget command line update does not remove old package references in .csproj when repository locations are different" (#6596) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Please read the following information before posting the issue.

## Details about Problem

NuGet product used (NuGet.exe | VS UI | Package Manager Console | dotnet.exe): NuGet.exe

NuGet version (x.x.x.xxx):4.3.0.4406 (obtained via VSTS NuGet Tool Installer task

dotnet.exe --version (if appropriate):

VS version (if appropriate):

OS version (i.e. win10 v1607 (14393.321)):Win Server 2016 v1607 (14393.2035)

Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version:

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. Have a C# project with a reference to a package using default repository location e.g. packages.
The .csproj file will have the following imports along with error messages for if these are not extant:
-  <Import Project="packages\<package name>\path\to\<package name>.props/> (If exists removed for clarity)
- <Import Project="packages\<package name>\path\to\<package name>.targets/>

2. have a later version package available.

3. invoke nuget update proj.sln -id <package name> -NonInteractive -RepositoryPath <something other than packages>
For example, on a VSTS Nuget task, 
update proj.sln -safe -Id package.name -NonInteractive -PreRelease -RepositoryPath $(Build.BinariesDirectory)\packages

Expected: The .csproj file would have the Import and Error checking lines REPLACED by the updated versions.

Actual: The new version Imports and error check lines are added, but the old versions remain.

If you remove the -RepositoryPath parameter, leaving it to use the default, the lines get replaced correctly.

The goal here is to update to the most recent CI-produced package when building on VSTS.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Pack doesn't find the installed nuget packages" (#6595) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
*From Paulo on mail:*

I have a project that has a dependency on Newtonsoft.Json version 10.0.3 and compiles just fine.
 
However, nuget pack throws this error:
 
Found packages.config. Using packages listed as dependencies
NuGet.CommandLine.CommandLineException: Unable to find 'Newtonsoft.Json.10.0.3.nupkg'. Make sure the project has been built.
   at NuGet.CommandLine.ProjectFactory.AddDependencies(Dictionary`2 packagesAndDependencies)
   at NuGet.CommandLine.ProjectFactory.ProcessDependencies(PackageBuilder builder)
   at NuGet.CommandLine.ProjectFactory.CreateBuilder(String basePath, NuGetVersion version, String suffix, Boolean buildIfNeeded, PackageBuilder builder)
   at NuGet.Commands.PackCommandRunner.BuildFromProjectFile(String path)
   at NuGet.CommandLine.PackCommand.ExecuteCommand()
   at NuGet.CommandLine.Command.ExecuteCommandAsync()
   at NuGet.CommandLine.Command.Execute()
   at NuGet.CommandLine.Program.MainCore(String workingDirectory, String[] args)
 
This also happens with other projects.
 
What am I missing?

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Update to mef imported nuget lock service in vs solution manager" (#6594) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody: We should analyze and change the `NuGetLockService` instance in `VSSolutionManager` to be MEF imported instead of creating a new one, which is currently done [here](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/98fd6e140c80c3932d6e857b456ee5120751ae46/src/NuGet.Clients/NuGet.PackageManagement.VisualStudio/IDE/VSSolutionManager.cs#L43).

Events.RelatedBody:
Eg.

C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio\2017\Enterprise\MSBuild\Microsoft\NuGet\15.0\Microsoft.NuGet.targets(178,5): Error : Your project is not referencing the "UAP,Version=v10.0.14393" framework. Add a reference to "UAP,Version=v10.0.14393" in the "frameworks" section of your project.json, and then re-run NuGet restore.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Deprecation of www.nuget.org/nuget.exe" (#20) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
|Spec wiki|Discussion issue|
|----------|------------------|
|*None*|https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/5381|

We are deprecating the use of URL: **www.nuget.org/nuget.exe** which currently downloads nuget.exe version 2.8.6. If you have a dependency on this URL, we recommend you to start using **https://dist.nuget.org/win-x86-commandline/v2.8.6/nuget.exe**. 

For consistency, we are also changing this endpoint to redirect to dist.nuget.org, which is our primary home for downloading all released versions of nuget.exe. 

**Old redirect:** https://az320820.vo.msecnd.net/downloads/nuget.exe 
**New redirect:** https://dist.nuget.org/win-x86-commandline/v2.8.6/nuget.exe

If you are interested in downloading newer versions of nuget.exe, please see the [Downloads](https://www.nuget.org/downloads) page on nuget.org.

For other methods of installing our client tools, please see our [Installing NuGet client tool](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/install-nuget-client-tools) documentation.

**Note:** There is no immediate plan to remove the URL **www.nuget.org/nuget.exe** . We will monitor the usage before taking it offline. We will also reach out again before taking the URL offline.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Deprecating the ability to copy Full access API keys" (#16) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
| Spec wiki| Discussion issue| 
| :------------- |:-------------| 
|*None*|[NuGet/NuGetGallery#5231](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/5231)|

We on the NuGet.org team are committed to continually seek ways to improve the security of our services. A year ago, we introduced [scoped API keys](https://blog.nuget.org/20170202/introducing-scoped-api-keys.html) to help our users better manage their API keys. While we recommend the use of scoped API keys, we will continue to support our legacy 'Full access API keys' that were previously granted by the service. Such keys do not expire if you use them at least one every 365 days to push a package.
 
We are making a change to our service such that a newly issued API key cannot be copied after the page is refreshed. While this was always the case for scoped API keys, we were allowing users with 'Full access API keys' to copy them down at any point. We plan to remove this capability in the future, as making this change allows us to migrate all of our APIs keys to use a one-way hash and further protect against malicious use of the key.

**Starting Feb 5th 2018, the 'Full access API key' cannot be copied from NuGet.org**. While most of the packages pushed to NuGet.org now use a scoped API key and are not impacted by this change, users continuing to use our legacy 'Full access API keys' will need to securely stash the key before this date after which they will not be accessible. Please note that the 'Full access API keys' will continue to work just like they did before. We are only removing the ability to copy them down from NuGet.org.

If you have further question, please reach out to us by commenting on the [discussion issue](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/5231) or send me an email at [anangaur@microsoft.com](mailto:anangaur@microsoft.com).
